column1: Required. If you change a name, you'll need to change any references to it on the Works page or here in relationships.
column10: Desired
column11: Desired.
column25: You can add other relationships, if they help

column10: English Biography
column11: Hebrew Biography
column15: Brill Online Reference Words (Encyclopedia of Jewish in the Islamic, Encyclopedia of the Hebrew Language, Encyclopedia of Judaism)

column10: Rabbi Shelomo ben Yitzhak, best known by the acronym Rashi, authored the most authoritative commentaries on the Tanakh and Talmud. He was also a halakhist who authored responsa. Rashi is known as the father of all commentators. There are no extant manuscripts of his works copied prior to his death. Rashi (1040-1105) was an early and very influential medieval Torah and Talmud commentator who lived in France. Rashi's commentary on the Bible is often considered an indispensable tool for Torah study. He described his aim as clarifying the "peshat" or "plain-sense" meaning of each verse.
column11: רבי שלמה בן יצחק, הידוע על פי ראשי התיבות רש"י, חיבר את הפירושים הסמכותיים ביותר לתנ"ך ולתלמוד. רש"י עסק גם בפסקי הלכה וחיבר שו"תים. הוא ידוע כ"אבי כל הפרשנים". לא נמצאים בידינו העתקים של כתבי יד שלו מלפני מותו. רש"י (1105-1040) חי בצרפת והיה פרשן תנ"ך ותלמוד קדום ובעל השפעה רבה. פירושו של רש"י על התנ"ך נחשב לעתים קרובות כלי הכרחי ללימוד תורה. המטרה שלו הייתה הבהרת הפשט, המשמעות הפשוטה של כל פסוק.

column25: Four sons, Rabbenu Tam, Rashbam, Isaac ben Meir, Solomon ben Meir

column2: Moshe ben Maimon, Maimonides, Moses Maimonides

column10: Rabbi Moshe ben Nachman authored commentaries on the Torah and the Talmud. He was a halakhist who wrote responsa and stand alone works on Halakhic issues as well as works on mysticism, science and philosophy.  Ramban (d.1270) was a Spanish scholar of Bible, Talmud, and Jewish Law.  Ramban's commentary on the Torah often critiques earlier commentaries, and incoporates Kabbalistic teachings.
column11: רבי משה בן נחמן חיבר פירושים על התורה והתלמוד. הוא היה איש הלכה שכתב שו"תים וחיבורים עצמאיים בנושאים הלכתיים, כמו גם חיבורים על מיסטיקה, מדע ופילוסופיה. הרמב"ן (שנפטר בשנת 1270) היה תלמיד חכם ספרדי שעסק בתנ"ך, תלמוד והלכה. פירושו של הרמב"ן על התורה לעתים קרובות מבקר פירושים קודמים, ומשלב את תורת קבלה.

column10: Rabbi Sh'muel ben Meir was the grandson of Rashi. He authored a commentary on the Torah that clung strictly to the concept of p'shat sometimes at the expense of received rabbinic traditions. He also wrote a commentary on portions of the Talmud. Rashbam (d. circa 1174) was a French Torah and Talmud commentator. Rashbam's commentary on the Torah provides a detailed "peshat" or "plain-sense" explanation of verse in the Bible.
column11: רבי שמואל בן מאיר היה נכדו של רש"י. הוא חיבר פירוש על התורה שדבק בקפדנות במושג ה"פשט", לפעמים על חשבון מסורות רבניות מקובלות. הוא כתב גם פירוש על חלקים של התלמוד. רשב"ם (שנפטר בסביבות 1174) היה פרשן תורה ותלמוד צרפתי. פירושו של רשב"ם על התורה מספק "פשט" מפורט של פסוק בתנ"ך.
column25: Had several students cf. Norman Golb

column2: Yonah Gerondi, Yonah ben Abraham Gerondi

column10: Avraham ben Meir was born in Spain but travelled extensively throughout his life. A gifted polymath he wrote an extensive commentary on the torah as well as on grammar, philosophy, astronomy, medicine, and mathematics. His poetry is still read and sung as part of the regular liturgy. Ibn Ezra (d. circa 1167) was a Spanish Torah commentator, who also wrote works on a number of other subjects, including Hebrew grammar and philosophy.  Ibn Ezra's Bible commentary often focuses on grammatical explanations and on the literal meaning of verses.
column11: אברהם בן מאיר נולד בספרד אבל נסע רבות במהלך חייו. איש אשכולות מוכשר, אבן עזרא כתב פרשנות נרחבת על התורה, כמו גם על דקדוק, פילוסופיה, אסטרונומיה, רפואה ומתמטיקה. השירה שלו עדיין נקראת ומושרת כחלק מן התפילה הקבועה. אבן עזרא (שנפטר בסביבות 1167) היה פרשן תורה ספרדי, שכתב גם חיבורים על כמה נושאים אחרים, לרבות דקדוק עברית ופילוסופיה. פרשנות המקרא של אבן עזרא לעתים קרובות מתמקדת בהסברים דקדוקיים ובמשמעות המילולית של פסוקים.
column25: Several people have the same name as him including the famous Moses Ibn Ezra, but it is disputed if they were related in more modern scholarship. Further research is necesary. He son was Isaac ibn Ezra.

column10: Shlomo Ephraim Luntschitz was the Chief Rabbi of Prague who wrote a commentary on the Torah, Keli Yakar (a precious vessel) as well as a number of other collections of homilies sermons. Rabbi Luntschitz (d. 1619) was a Polish rabbi and orator who is best known for his Torah commentary, Kli Yakar. Keli Yakar is a commentary on the Torah written in a homiletical style.
column11: רבי שלמה אפרים מלונטשיץ היה הרב הראשי של פראג והוא כתב את הפירוש "כלי יקר" על התורה, וכן כמה אוספים אחרים של דרשות. הרבי מלונטשיץ (שנפטר בשנת 1619) היה רב פולני ונואם, והוא ידוע בעיקר בזכות פרשנותו לתורה. ה"כלי יקר" הוא פירוש על התורה שכתוב בסגנון של מדרש.

column10: Rabbi Ovadia ben Yaakov Sforno wrote a commentary on the Torah that sticks to the pshat school. He also wrote works on philosophy and commentaries on a number of books of Tanakh. Sforno is also quoted in responsa of contemporary authorities who consulted him on issues of halakha. Rabbi Ovadiah ben Ya'akov Seforno (d. 1550) was an Italian exegete, philosopher, and physician. Seforno's Torah commentary focuses on the literal meaning of the text, avoids kabbalistic explanations, and sometimes incorporates his knowledge of medicine to help explain verses.
column11: רבי עובדיה בן יעקב ספורנו כתב פירוש על התורה שדבק בדוקטורינת ה"פשט". הוא כתב גם חיבורים בפילוסופיה ופירושים על כמה מספרי התנ"ך. ספורנו מצוטט אף בשו"תים של חכמים בני זמננו שנעזרו בו בענייני הלכה. רבי עובדיה בן יעקב ספורנו (שנפטר ב-1550) חי באיטליה ופעל כדרשן, פילוסוף ורופא. פירוש ספורנו לתורה מתמקד במשמעות המילולית של הכתוב, נמנע מהסברים מתורת הקבלה, ולעתים אף מכיל ידע רפואי כדי להסביר פסוקים מסוימים.

column2: Nissim of Gerona, Nissim ben Reuven

column10: The Tosafists (12th - 13th centuries) are primarily noted for the commentary on the Talmud. Da'at Zekeinim is a Torah commentary that generally provides "peshat" or "straighforward" interpretations of the text.
column11: בעלי התוספות (המאות ה-12 וה-13) ידועים בעיקר בזכות פירושם לתלמוד. דעת זקנים הוא פירוש לתורה שבדרך כלל מספק פירושי "פשט" לכתוב.

column2: Raavad, Avraham ben David of Posquières
column19: Moses ben Joseph, Meshullam of Lunel
Rav Nissim Gaon, Hananel ben Hushiel

column10: Rabbi Asher ben Yehiel (d. 1328) was a prominent Talmudist, best known for his summary of laws extracted from the Talmud. He was born in Spain and later moved to Germany. The Rosh's commentary on the Torah was preserved with the commentaries of a number of the Tosafist and included in a collection of those works.
column11: רבי אשר בן יחיאל (נפטר 1328) היה איש תלמוד חשוב והוא ידוע בעיקר בזכות סיכום ההלכות שחיבר על בסיס התלמוד. הוא נולד בספרד ומאוחר יותר עבר לגרמניה. פירושו של הרא"ש על התורה נשמר עם פירושם של כמה מבעלי התוספות והוא נכלל באוסף של חיבורים אלה.
column19: Mazliach ibn al-Basaq, Moses ha-Darshan, Moses Kalfo

column25: Son In law Moses ben Isaac Bonems

column10: Rabbi Chayyim Ibn Atar (d. 1743) was a Moroccan Torah commentator, halakhic decisor, and kabbalist. Or HaChayyim is a Torah commentary which often incorporates Kabbalistic teachings to elucidate the verses of the Bible.
column11: רבי חיים בן עטר (נפטר 1743) היה פרשן תורה מרוקאי, פוסק הלכה ומקובל. "אור החיים" הוא פירוש לתורה שלעתים קרובות משלב רעיונות קבליים כדי להסביר את הפסוקים בתנ"ך.

column19: Isaac ben Moses of Vienna,  Yehiel of Paris, Samuel ben Solomon of Falaise, Samuel of Evreux

column10: Rabbi Jacob ben Asher (d. circa 1340) was born in Germany but lived most of his life in Spain. He is most famous for having composed the great law code, Arba'ah Turim. Ba'al HaTurim HaShalem is a commentary on the Torah which draws on the works of other commentators, particularly that of Ramban.
column11: רבי יעקב בן אשר (נפטר 1340) נולד בגרמניה אך חי את רוב חייו בספרד. חיבורו המפורסם ביותר הוא ספרי ההלכה - ה"ארבעה טורים". בעל הטורים השלם הוא פירוש על התורה שמסתמך על פירושם של פרשנים אחרים, במיוחד הרמב"ן.

column10: Abarbanel (d. 1508) was a Bible commentator, philosopher, and statesman. Born in Portugal, he lived much of his life in Spain, and died in Venice. Abarbanel's commentary always begins with a number of questions about the text at hand, which he answers over the course of his exegesis.
column11: אברבנאל (נפטר 1508) היה פרשן תנ"ך, פילוסוף ומדינאי. הוא נולד בפורטוגל, חי את רוב חייו בספרד ונפטר בוונציה. פירושו של אברבנאל תמיד מתחיל בכמה שאלות על הכתוב של אותו פרק, ועליהן הוא עונה במהלך פירושו.

column2: Meir Levush ben Yehiel Michael Wieser
column4: מאיר ליבוש בן יחיאל מיכל וייזר
column10: Rabbi Meir Leivush Weisser, known as Malbim, (d.1879) was a scholar, orator, and Torah commentator who traveled and lived in a number of locations in Eastern Europe. Malbim is a Torah commentary which attempts to defend the traditional approach to Torah study against the innovations of the Reform movement, and to show that the Oral Law is deeply rooted in the text of the Bible.
column11: רבי מאיר ליבוש וייזר, הידוע בכינויו המלבי"ם (נפטר 1879), היה מלומד, דורש ופרשן תורה שגר בכמה מקומות במזרח אירופה. המלבי"ם הוא פירוש לתורה שמנסה להגן על הגישה המסורתית ללימוד תורה מול החידושים של התנועה הרפורמית, ולהראות שהתורה שבעל פה נטועה עמוק בכתוב בתנ"ך.

column2: David Ben Yosef Kamhi, David Ben Yosef Kimhi
column10: Rabbi David Kimchi (d. 1235) was a French Torah scholar, philosopher, and Hebrew grammarian. Radak's Bible commentary frequently focuses on grammatical and etymological issues within the verses.
column11: רבי דוד קמחי (נפטר 1235) חי בצרפת היה ותלמיד חכם, פילוסוף ומדקדק. פירושו של רד"ק מתמקד הרבה בעניינים דקדוקיים ואטימולוגיים בתוך הפסוקים.

column10: Rabbi Meir Simchah of Dvinsk (d.1926) was a Lithuanian rabbi who wrote on issues of Jewish law and Talmud, in addition to his Torah commentary. Meshekh Chochmah is a philosophically-inclined commentary which if often noted for its originality and depth.
column11: רבי מאיר שמחה מדווינסק (נפטר 1926) חי בליטא וכתב דברים הנודעים לענייני הלכה ותלמוד, נוסף על פירושו לתורה. משך חכמה הוא פירוש עם נטייה פילוסופית שמצוין לעתים קרובות כבעל מקוריות ועומק יוצאים מן הכלל.

column10: Rabbi Chizkiah ben Manoach lived in the thirteenth century, probably in France. The details of his biography are unknown. Chizkuni is a commentary on the Torah which quotes earlier commentators, particularly Rashi, and further explains these comments, as well as the verses they elucidate.
column11: רבי חזקיה בן מנוח חי במאה ה-13, כנראה בצרפת. פרטי הביוגרפיה שלו אינם ידועים. החזקוני הוא פירוש לתורה שמצטט פרשנים קדומים יותר, בעיקר את רש"י, ומסביר פירושים אלה ואת הפסוקים שאותם הם מבהירים.

column10: Rabbi Levi ben Gershon (d. 1344) was a French philosopher, mathemetician, astrologer, and Torah commentator. Ralbag's Torah commentary includes an explanation of the words of each section, a commentary on the meaning, and an exploration of the deeper meanings and morals that emerge.
column11: רבי לוי בן גרשון (נפטר 1344) היה פילוסוף צרפתי, מתמטיקאי, אסטרולוג ופרשן תורה. פירוש רלב"ג לתורה כולל הסבר על המילים בכל פסוק, פירוש המשמעות שבו, וחקר המשמעויות העמוקות יותר והמסרים העולים מהכתוב.

column10: Moshe Alshikh (d. 1593) was a rabbi and orator who was born in the Ottoman Empire and lived in Safed. Moshe Alshikh's Torah commentary, called Torat Moshe, is based on the lectures he gave on the weekly Torah portion. It is a homiletical commentary which extracts moral lessons from the verses.
column11: משה אלשייך (נפטר 1593) היה רב ודרשן שנולד באימפריה העות'מנית וחי בצפת. פירושו של רבי משה אלשייך, המכונה "תורת משה", מבוסס על הדרשות השבועויות שלו על פרשת השבוע. פירושו הוא בסגנון אגדה והוא מוציא מתוך הכתוב עניינים במוסר.

column2: Bahya ibn Pequdah, Bachya ibn Pekuda
column10: Rabbi Bachya ben Asher (d. circa 1340) was a Spanish Torah scholar and orator who is best known for his Torah commentary.
column11: רבנו בחיי בן אשר (נפטר בסביבות 1340) חי בספרד והיה תלמיד חכם ודרשן, והוא ידוע בעיקר בזכות פירושו לתורה.

column10: Rabbi Shimshon Refael Hirsch (d. 1888) was a German scholar, writer and activist. He pioneered a neo-Orthodox movement that championed engagement with Western culture while also maintaining strict observance of Jewish law. Rabbi Shimshon Refael Hirsch's Torah commentary carefully analyzes the language of the Torah and often explains the deeper meanings of commandments.
column11: הרב שמשון רפאל הירש (נפטר 1888) היה מלומד גרמני, סופר ופעיל פוליטית. היה החלוץ של תנועה נאו-אורתודוקסית שדגלה בשילוב העולם המערבי עם שמירת מצוות אדוקה. פירושו של הרש"ר הירש מנתח בזהירות את הלשון בתורה ומסביר את המשמעויות העמוקות שבמצוות.

column10: Rabbi Barukh HaLevi Epstein (d.1941) was a Lithuanian rabbi and scholar, who is best known for his Torah commentary, the Torah Temimah. Torah Temimah is a commentary on the Torah which cites all Talmudic or Midrashic references to a particular verse and provides explanations.
column11: הרב ברוך הלוי אפשטיין (נפטר 1941) היה רב ומלומד ליטאי שידוע בעיקר בזכות פירושו לתורה, "תורה תמימה". תורה תמימה היא פירוש על התורה שמביא את כל האזכורים מהתלמוד או ממדרשים לפסוק מסוים ומספק הסברים.

column10: Netsiv (d. 1893) was a Lithuanian rabbi and scholar, and was the head of the prominent Volozhin Yeshiva. HaEmek Davar is a Torah commentary, based on the Netsiv's classes on the weekly Torah portion, which explores the deeper meaning of each verse, and shows how Rabbinic law is closely connected to the Biblical text.
column11: הנצי"ב (נפטר 1893) היה רב ומלומד ליטאי וראש ישיבת וולוז'ין. העמק דבר הוא פירוש לתורה שמבוסס על שיעורי הנצי"ב על פרשת השבוע, והוא מתחקה אחר המשמעות העמוקה של כל פסוק ומראה כיצד הלכה רבנית קשורה לכתוב בתנ"ך.
column18: Yitzchok of Volozhin, Yechiel Michel Epstein

column10: Rabbi Yitschak ben Moshe Arama (d. 1494) was a Spanish Talmudist and philosophically-oriented exegete. Akeidat Yitschak is a Torah commentary which is philosophical and also imparts moral and ethical teachings.
column11: הרב יצחק בן משה עראמה (נפטר 1494) חי בספרד והיה בעל גמרא ופרשן בעל נטייה פילוסופית. "עקידת יצחק" היא פירוש לתורה בעל אופי פילוסופי ורווי שיעורים במוסר ובאתיקה.

column10: Rabbi Yosef Dov Soloveitchik (d. 1892) was a Lithuanian scholar and served as rabbi in a number of communities, culminating in his appointment as rabbi of Brisk. Beit HaLevi is a Torah commentary which ilustrates the connections between Midrash and rabbinic law, and the text of the Torah.
column11: הרב יוסף דוב סולובייצ'יק (נפטר 1892) היה תלמיד חכם ליטאי שכיהן כרב בכמה קהילות עד שמונה להיות הרב של בריסק. "בית הלוי" הוא פירוש לתורה שקושר בין מדרש להלכה ולכתוב בתורה.

column3: העשיל מקראקא, אברהם יהושע העשל מקראקא
column10: Rabbi Abraham Joshua ben Jacob Heschel (d. 1664) was a Lithuanian scholar and teacher, and later in his life became the head of the yeshiva in Cracow. Chanukkat HaTorah is a commentary on the Torah which gathers earlier rabbinic sayings and uses them to answer questions about each verse.
column11: הרב אברהם יהושע בן יעקב השל (נפטר 1664) היה תלמיד חכם ומורה ליטאי, ובהמשך חייו הפך לראש הישיבה בקרקוב. "חנוכת התורה" היא פירוש לתורה שאוסף אמרות רבניות קדומות ומשתמש בהן כדי לענות על שאלות מכל פסוק.
column25: Brother in law, Zechariah Mendel ben Aryeh Leib,  Samuel ben Uri Shraga Phoebus, Yehezkiah Joshua Feivel Teomim

column10: Rabbi Menachem ben Binyamin Recanati was an Italian kabbalist and halakhic decisor. Recanati's Torah commentary draws upon kabbalistic sources to explain the verses of the Torah.
column11: הרב מנחם בן בנימין רקנטי היה מקובל ופוסק הלכה איטלקי. הפירוש של רקנטי לתורה משתמש במקורות קבליים כדי להסביר את הפסוקים בתורה.

column2: Aderet Eliyahu, HaGra, Elijah ben Shlomo Zalman from Vilna

column19: Avraham ben Shabtai Sheftel Horowitz, Meir Lublin, Joshua Falk

column10: Rabbi Avraham Saba (d. 1508) was a Spanish teacher and exegete who spent much of his life fleeing persecution. Tseror HaMor is a commentary on the Torah which incorporates mystical explanations from the Zohar.
column11: רבי אברהם סבע (נפטר 1508) היה מורה ופרשן ספרדי שנאלץ רוב חייו לברוח מרדיפות. "צרור המור" הוא פירוש על התורה שמשלב בתוכו הסברים מיסטיים מהזוהר.

column10: Rabbi Mecklenberg (d.1865) was a German rabbi and Torah scholar. HaKetav VeHakabbalah is a Torah commentary designed to demonstrate the close connections between Rabbinic law and the Biblical text.
column11: הרב יעקב צבי מקלנבורג (נפטר 1865) היה רב ותלמיד חכם גרמני. "הכתב והקבלה" הוא פירוש לתורה שמטרתו להראות את הקשר הקרוב בין הלכה לטקסט התנ"כי.

column10: Rabbi Yitschak ben Asher Halevi (11th century) was an early Tosafist who lived in Speyer and was a student of Rashi, the great Talmud and Torah commentator. Riv"a's Torah commentary is preserved in texts from other Tosafists (Talmud commentators) of his time.
column11: הרב יצחק בן אשר הלוי (המאה ה-11) היה בעל תוספות מוקדם שחי בשפייר והיה תלמיד של רש"י, פרשן התורה והתלמוד הידוע. פירוש הריב"א לתורה נשמר בכתבים מבעלי תוספות אחרעם בדורו.

column10: Rabbi Hayyim Yosef David Azulai (d. 1806) was a scholar and a prolific writer and publisher. He was born in Jerusalem, and spent much of his life traveling throughout the Jewish communities of Europe.
column11: הרב חיים יוסף דוד אזולאי (נפטר 1806) היה תלמיד חכם, סופר ומוציא לאור. הוא נולד בירושלים ובילה את רוב חייו בנסיעות לקהילות שונות באירופה.

column2: R. Velvel Soloveitchik, Yizhak Zev Halevi Soloveitchik
column10: Rabbi Yitschak Zev HaLevi Soloveitchik (d. 1959), also known as the "Brisker Rav," was the head of the Brisk Yeshiva in Jerusalem. The Gri"z (which stands for Gaon Rabbi Yitschak Zev) is famous for his conceptual approach to all texts, including in his Torah commentary.
column11: הרב יצחק זאב הלוי סולובייצ'יק (נפטר 1959), הידוע גם בכינויו "הרב מבריסק", היה ראש ישיבת בריסק בירושלים. הגרי"ז (ראשי תיבות של הגאון רבי יצחק זאב) ידוע בזכות גישתו הקונספטואלית לכל הטקסטים, כולל פירושו לתורה.

column10: Rabbi Yosef ben Meir Teomim (d.1792) was a Galician halakhist and teacher. He is best known for his legal commentaries on the Shulkhan Arukh, the great sixteenth-century law code.
column11: הרב יוסף בן מאיר תאומים (נפטר 1792) חי בגליציה והיה איש הלכה ומורה. הוא ידוע בזכות הפירושים ההלכתיים שלו על השולחן ערוך, ספר ההלכה החשוב מהמאה ה-16.

column10: Rabbi Yitschak Karo (d. 1535) was a Spanish teacher, halakhic decisor, and physician. Toldot Yitschak is a commentary on the five books of the Torah
column11: רבי יצחק קארו (נפטר 1535) חי בספרד והיה מורה, פוסק הלכה ורופא. "תולדות יצחק" הוא פירוש על חמישה חומשי תורה.

column2: David ben Josef ben David Abudarham
column4: דוד בן יוסף בן דוד אבודרהם

column10: Rabbi Benno Jacob (d. 1945) was a Reform German rabbi who also had an academic degree in Semitics. Rabbi Benno Jacob's Torah commentary explains each verse in depth in order to show the internal logic of the Torah and to disprove the Documentary Hypothesis.
column11: הרב בנו יעקב (נפטר 1945) היה רב גרמני רפורמי בעל תואר אקדמי בשפות השמיות. פירושו לתורה מסביר כל פסוק לעומק כדי להראות את ההיגיון הפנימי של התורה ולסתור את תורת התעודות.

column10: Rabbi Chayyim Paltiel was a 13th century French Torah commentator.
column11: רבי חיים פלטיאל היה פרשן תורה צרפתי מהמאה ה-13.

column10: Rabbi Ovadiah MiBartenura (d. circa 1515) was an Italian scholar who was most famous for his Mishnah commentary. Rabbi Ovadiah MiBartenura's Torah commentary elucidates Rashi's comments on the Torah.
column11: רבי עובדיה מברטנורא (נפטר בסביבות 1515) היה תלמיד חכם איטלקי שידוע בעיקר בזכות פירושו למשנה. פירושו של רבי עובדיה מברטנורא מבהיר את פירושו של רש"י על התורה.

column10: Rabbi Eliyahu Mizrachi (d. circa 1525) was a talmudist and halakhic decisor who served as Chief Rabbi of the Ottoman Empire. Sefer HaMizrachi is a supercommentary on Rashi's Torah commentary, which explains Rashi's sources and elucidates his comments.
column11: הרב אליהו מזרחי (נפטר בסביבות 1525) היה בעל גמרא ופוסק הלכה שכיהן כרב הראשי של האימפריה העות'מנית. ספר המזרחי הוא פירוש על פירושו של רש"י לתורה. הוא מסביר את המקורות של רש"י ומבהיר את הפירושים שלו.

column10: Rabbi David Altshul was an 18th century Torah commentator. Metsudat David is a commentary on Prophets and Writings that is designed to help the reader understand the meaning of the text. Metsudat Tsion is essentially a dictionary for difficult words in the Bible; the words are listed and translated.
column11: הרב דוד אלטשול היה פרשן תורה שחי במאה ה-18. "מצודת דוד" הוא פירוש על הנביאים והכתובים שמטרתו לעזור ללומד להבין את משמעות הכתוב. "מצודת ציון" הוא למעשה מילון למילים קשות בתנ"ך; המילים רשומות ומתורגמות.

column10: Rabbi Yedidiah Solomon ben Abraham Nortsi (d. 1626) was an Italian rabbi and Biblical scholar. Minchat Shai is a critical commentary of the Bible which presents all of the variant readings from within Rabbinic literature.
column11: הרב ידידיה שלמה בן אברהם נורצי (נפטר 1626) היה רב איטלקי וחוקר מקרא. מנחת שי הוא פרשנות ביקורתית על התנ"ך המציגה את כל קריאות הגרסה מתוך ספרות חז"ל.

column10: Rabbi Yoel Sirkes (d. 1640) was a Polish rabbi, halakhic scholar and talmudic annotator. His best-know work, Bait Chadash, is one of the basic commentaries (together with R Yosef Karo's Beit Yosef) on R. Yaakov ben Asher's halachic code, the Arba'ah Turim. Hagahot Habach are his indispensible glosses on the text of the Talmud. The Taz was his son-in-law.

Rabbi Shabbatai Hakohen (d. 1662) was a Lithuanian/Polish rabbi, halakhic scholar and talmudist. His best-know work, Siftei Kohen, is one of the basic commentaries on the Shulchan Aruch (on the sections Yoreh Deah and Choshen Mishpat). His rulings were widely accepted by Ashkenazic Jewry as authoritative. He wrote critical commentaries on the Turei Zahav, the other great commentary on the Shulchan Aruch.

Rabbi David Halevi Segal (d. 1667) was a Polish rabbi, halakhic scholar and talmudist. His best-known work, Turei Zahav, is one of the basic commentaries on the Shulchan Aruch (on all four sections, most prominently on Yoreh Deah and Orach Chayyim). He responded to the Shach's critiques of his expositions and decisions in a separate work. and also authored Divrei David, a supercommentary on Rashi's Torah commentary. The Bach was his father-in-law

Rabbi Yaakov Emden (d. 1776) was a German rabbi, talmudist and polemecist. He is most well-known for his publically promoted and literarily defended identification of Rabbi Yonatan Eibeschutz as a hidden Sabbatean. He published many works, amongst which is a highly regarded and republished siddur with extensive commentary, and a collection of responsa, She'ilat Ya'avetz. His father was the Chacham Tzvi.

Rabbi Yom-Tov Lipmann Heller (d. 1654), was a Bohemian rabbi and talmudist. His best-known work, Tosafot Yom Tov, is one of the basic commentaries on the Mishnah. He also wrote Ma'adanei Yom Tov, an important commentary on Piskei HaRosh of Rabbi Asher ben Yechiel. He studied under the Maharal of Prague, and served as rabbi of Vienna and Prague. Many prominent rabbis of subsequent generations are his descendants.

Martin Buber (Feb. 8, 1878 - June 13, 1965) was a Jewish scholar and philosopher best known for his existentialist work I and Thou (Ich und Du) He was born in an Orthodox home in Vienna and raised in Lvov, but later returned to Vienna to study modern philosphy. He was a scholar, translator and explicator of Hasidic lore, which he compiled in Tales of the Hasidim. He was an ardent Zionist, settling in Jerusalem in 1938, where he became a professor at the Hebrew University.

Solomon (or Salomon) Buber (Feb. 2, 1827 - 1906) was a scholar and editor of Hebrew works, particularly known for his original research and prolific explication of Midrashic literature. He wrote elaborate and exhaustive commentaries of Midrashic works including Pesikhta de-Rab Kahana, Midrash Abkir, Midrash Tanchuma, Midrash Tehillim, Midrash Shmuel and Midrash Mishle. He was also the primary teacher of his grandson, Martin Buber, who lived with him from the age of three.

Rabbi Eliyahu David Rabinowitz Teomim (d. 1905. known by his acronym, Aderet), was a Lithuanian rabbi and talmudist who served, toward the end of his life, as leader of the Ashkenazic community in Jerusalem.  He wrote many works, filled with original insights, in all areas of Torah. Rabbi Avraham Yitzchak Hakohen Kook was his son-in-law.

column2: Yaakov ben Yaakov Moshe Lorberbaum of Lissa, Ba'al HaChavat Da'at, Ba'al HaNesivot, the Rav of Lissa
column10: Rabbi Yaakov Lorberbaum (d. 1832), was a Polish rabbi, talmudist and halachic decisor. His best-known works, Chavot Da'at, on Shulchan Aruch Yoreh De'ah and Netivot Mishpat, on Shulchan Aruch Choshen Mishpat have had a formative impact on classic Torah study to the present day. He was a great-grandson of the Chacham Tzvi.
column25: Relative of Jacob Emden and Joseph Teomim

column2: Yismach Yisrael, Yerachmiel Israel Yitzchak Dancyger
column10: Rabbi Yirachmiel Yisrael Danziger (d. 1910) was the second Rebbe of the Alexander Chassidic dynasty in Poland. His work, Yismach Yisrael, focuses on practical piety and is widely learned in other Chassidic circles as well. He emphasized ecstatic prayer in worship.

Rabbi Avraham Yitzchak Hakohen Kook (d. 1935) was a towering Torah personality and tremendously influential leader in Lithuania and the Land of Israel. A master of almost every facet of Jewish literature, he wrote halachic and aggadic works, as well as philosophical and mystical tracts, responsa and commentaries. His voluminous correspondence covers every imaginable topic. He served as chief rabbi of Yaffo and as the first modern chief rabbi of the entire Jewish community of the Land of Israel.

Rabbi Moshe Chaim Luzzatto (d. 1707) was an Italian rabbi, kabbalist and philosopher who also wrote dramatic worrks and literary criticism. Gifted with an almost photographic memory, he wrote many works, some which became standards of kabbalah and ethics. He was suspected of Sabbateanism but exonerated by his teachers and colleagues, with a warning to cease engaging in speculative kabbalistic writing. Toward the end of his life, he moved to the Land of Israel.

column2: Joseph ben Ephraim Karo, Maran, Hamehaber
column10: Rabbi Yosef Karo (d. 1575), expelled from Spain as a child, was a rabbi, talmudist, mystic and a pre-emiment halakhic codifier. His best-known work, the Shulchan Aruch, was accepted in his lifetime and subsequently as the definitive statement of Jewish legal and religious practice. He also wrote basic commentaries on the Mishneh Torah and the Arba'ah Turim (the latter forming the basis from which the Shulchan Aruch was distilled). He was also a mystic who received heavenly revelations. Some of these were set down in writing and formed the impetus to come to the Land of Israel. There, he lived in Tsfat, where he took a central role in the attempt by his teacher, R.Yaakov Berav, to revive traditional rabbinic Semichah.
column18: Isaac Saba, Hayyim Albalag,  Zechariah Sechsel

column10: Rabbi Moshe Cordovero, also referred to as RaMak, (d. 1570) was a leading Kabbalist who lived and taught in Tsfat, in Land of Israel. His best-known work, Pardes Rimmonim, is a systematation of various school of Kabbalistic thought. He many highly influential works, included a defense of Kabbalah, an highly-regarded ethical work based of Kabbalistic thought, and a comprehsive commentary on the Zohar. He had many disciples and was considered the premier Kabbalistic authority until superceded by R. Yitzchak Luria shortly after his death.

column2: Nachman of Breslov, Nahman of Breslov, Nachman of Bratzlav, Rebbe Nachman, Rebbe Nahman
column10: Rabbi Nachman of Breslov (d. 1810) was one of the most creative Chassidic masters, whose thought and teachings continue to resonate within wide circles far beyond his immediate followers. He was a great-grandson of the founder of Chassidut, R. Yisrael Ba'al Shem Tov, and a grandson of another early Chassidic master, R. Nachman of Horodenka. Among his many works are a profound presentation of his Chassidic and mystical teaching, Likkutei Moharan, and a compilation of his intricate and powerfully evocative stories, Sippurei Ma'asiyot.  Another work relates the events of his transformatic journey to and trom the Land of Israel. He was severely criticized by certain contemporary Chassidic masters, but defended by the leading Chassidic master, R. Levi Yitzchak of Berdichev. He moved to Uman less than a year before he passed away from tuberculosis, and his grave there is a pilgrimage site for thousands to this day.

Rabbi Shneur Zalman of Liady (d. 1812), was the founder of Lubavitch (Chabad) Chassidut. He was a leading disciple of the Maggid of Mezeritch, who send his to Lithuania to spread Chassidut and assigned him the task of composed a Shulchan Aruch which reflected Chassidic practices (Shulchan Aruch HaRav). His best-know work is the vastly influential Likkutei Amarim, better known as Tanya.  He wrote other works of Chassidut and Kabbalah, including Torah Or and Likkutei Torah. In the dispute between Chassidim and Mitnagdim, he was falsely accused of fomenting rebellion against the Tsar and imprisoned. His release from prision, considered to portend profound developments, is celebrated by Chabad Chassidim to this day. He was succeeded as Rebbe by his son, R. Dov Baer.
column25: Greatgrand son of Maharal of Prague

column4: ר' צדקיה בן ר' אברהם הרופא הענוים
column10: Zedekiah ben Abraham Anav (d. 1280), was an Italian Rabbi and halachist. His work, Shibbolei Haleket, was a halachic compendium which was referenced extensively by subsequent halachists.
column19: Jacob of Wurzburg, Abigdor Cohen of Vienna

column10: Betsalel ben Avraham Ashkenazi (1592), was an Egyptian rabbi and talmudist. His best-known work is Shittah Mekubetzet, a highly influential compendium of earlier commentaries on a number of key Talmudic tractates. He was a student of the Rabbi David ben Solomon ibn Abi Zimra (the Radbaz) and R. Yitzchak Luria was his student. Toward the end of his life, he travelled to the Land of Israel and served as chief rabbi in Jerusalem, resolving a serious dispute between subcommunities.
column19: David ben Solomon ibn Abi Zimra, Israel de Curial

column10: Rabbi Marcus Jastrow (1829 - 1903) was a Talmudic scholar and author of A Dictionary of the Targumim, Talmud Babli, Talmud Yerushalmi and Midrashic Literature, popularly known as "The Jastrow." He was also the rabbi of the Orthodox congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia from 1866 to 1892. Under his leadership, the congregation acquired an organ and was initially allowed to join the Reform movement. However, after the Reform Movement rallied around its radical "Pittsburgh Platform," he withdrew his congregation from the movement.

Yosef Hayyim (1832-1909), also known as the Ben-Ish Chai, was the Chacham of the Jewish community of Baghdad. He was a preminent authority on halachah and a master kabbalist. His work the Ben Ish Chai, based on his classes on the weekly Torah reading, contain both kabbalistic insights into the Torah portion as well as practical laws for everyday life.
column19: Eliyahu Hayyim, David Hai b. Meir

column10: Rabbi Shlomo ben Joseph Ganzfried (1804-1886) was the author of the Kitzur Shulchan Aruch. He was rabbi of Brezevitz for many years before returning to his hometown of Ungvar (Austrian Empire/Ukraine) to serve as a dayan on the rabbinical court. In his role of community leader, Ganzfried came to believe that every Jew needed to know and understand Jewish law if Orthodoxy was to survive. To that end he composed the Kitzur Shulchan Aruch, which was widely popular and published both in Hebrew and in Yiddish.

Rabbi Israel Meir (HaKohen) Kagan (1839–1933), also known as the Chofetz Chaim, was a Lithuanian rabbi of the Musar movement. He was a יalakhist, posek and ethicist whose seminal works, the Chafetz Chaim and Shmirat HaLashon, have come to define the rules of proper speech. He also composed the Mishnah Berurah, a 6-volume commentary on the Orach Chaim section of the Shulchan Aruch. He was briefly the rabbi of Radun (Poland/Belarus), but resigned in order to found the Radun Yeshiva.

Rabbi Yechiel Michel Epstein (1829-1908) was also known as "the Aruch ha-Shulchan" after his יgreat halachic work by that name. He was a posek and the rabbi of Navardok, where he served for 34 years. He was married to the sister of Rabbi Naftali Zvi Yehudah Berlin (HaNatziv). He was known for his charitable works, particularly for his support of the Rebbi Meir Baal HaNeis charity fund which funded the Jews of Eretz Yisrael.
column25: Brother in law  Naftali Zvi Yehuda Berlin

column10: Rabbi Yitzhak Yosef was born January 16, 1952 in Jerusalem. The son of Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, he is the Sephardi Chief Rabbi for the State of Israel (the Rishon Lezion), as well as the rosh yeshiva of Yeshivat Hazon Ovadia. He has written many foundational works for Sephardi Jews in Israel and the world, including Yalkut Yosef, a popular compendium of Jewish Law.

Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef  (September 24, 1920 – October 7, 2013) was the Sephardi Chief Rabbi of Israel from 1973 to 1983 and the greatest halachic authority for Sephardic Jewry in the modern era. He was born in Baghdad and made aliyah to Jerusalem with his family at the age of four. In 1950 he was appointed dayan to the rabbinical court of Petach Tikva, where he issued the first of the many bold and innovative rulings that marked his career. In 1984 he became a noteable figure in Israeli politics in founding the ultra-Orthodox Sephardi party Shas, serving as its spiritual leader until his death in 2013.

column25: Brother in law Samuel ben Uri Shraga Phoebus, Yehezkiah Joshua Feivel Teomim, Heshel of Krakow

column10: Rabbi Louis Ginzberg (November 28, 1873 - November 11, 1953), was a Talmudist and leading figure in the Conservative Movement. He was born in Kaunus, Vilna, to a religious family that traced it's lineage to the Gaon of Vilna. He came to America in 1899 and began teaching Talmud in 1902 at the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York, where he remained until his death. He is best known for his commentary on the Talmud Yerushalmi and for his 6-volume collection of aggadic literature, The Legends of the Jews.

column25: Brother Menahem ben Helbo, Son Joseph Kara

column10: Rabbi Yehudah Leib Halevi Ashlag, also known as the Baal HaSulam  (1885-1954), was a rabbi and a kabbalist. He was born In Lodz to a scholarly family connected to the Hasidic courts of Porisov and Belz. In 1921 he made aliyah, where he was appointed rabbi of Givat Shaul, Jerusalem. He is best known for his work Talmud Eser Sefirot, a commentary and re-editing of the work of Isaac Luria, as well as Sulam, a commentary on the Zohar.

Rebbe Levi Yitzchok of Berditchev (1740–1809), was also known as "The Berditchever Rabbi" after the community he served for 25 years . A childhood illuy (genius) from a prominent rabbinic family, he chose to study Chasidut under the Maggid of Mezritch for many years. His love of the Jewish people and his charitable interpretations of their actions before Hashem are legendery, as was as his fervor in prayer and enthusiastic dedication to mitzvot. He is the author of the Kedushat Levi, a collection of chasidic insights into the weekly Torah portion.
column19: Maggid of Mezritch, Shmekle of Nikolsburg,

column10: Rebbe Yitzchak Meir Rotenberg-Alter (1799-1866), also known as "The Rim," was the first rebbe of the Ger Hasidic dynasty. He was a Talmudic genius from a distinguished line of German and Polish rabbis that included Rashi and the Tosafist, Rabbi Meir ben Baruch of Rothenburg. His hasidut was influenced by the Koznitzer Maggid, Reb Simcha Bunim of Prshischa and the Kotzker Rebbe, of whom he was a disciple. He established his own dynasty in the Polish town of Góra Kalwaria, or "Ger," in Yiddish. He is known for his work Chiddushei HaRim.

Rabbi Yisroel (Israel) ben Eliezer (c 1700-1760), also known as the Baal Shem Tov (the Besh"t), was the founder of the Hasidic movement. Of humble and obscure origins, he was introduced to the secrets of kabbalah by Rabbi Adam Baal Shem of Ropczyce and other masters of practical kabbalah. In 1734 he presented himself to the world as a "Baal Shem," a "Master of the Name," the title used for holy men who could work miracles. His teachings made kabbalistic teachings accessibile to the common Jew, and emphasized ways of drawing closer to the Divine besides the traditional framework of Torah study. He was followed as leader of the nascent Hasidic movement by Rabbi Dov Baer the Maggid of Mezeritch.

column25: Brother in Law Abraham Gershon of Kitov

column10: Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson (1902 - 1994), known as "The Rebbe," was the last Chabad-Lubavitcher rebbe and the pioneer of the Jewish outreach movement. Under his leadership, Chabad emerged from relative obscurity to become one of the most influential forces of Jewish life in the 20th century. Escaping Nazi Europe, he arrived in New York in 1941, where he became the head of Chabad's educational and social service networks. He immediately established the "shlichut" system, sending pairs of yeshiva students to far-flung Jewish communities to reconnect Jews to their heritage. He also worked actively internationally, helping to free thousands of Iranian Jews during the 1979 revolution, and later providing for the religious and educational needs of Jews trapped inside the Soviet Union.

column19: Aryeh Leib ben Asher Gunzberg, Vilna Gaon

column25: Son of Rebbe Nahman of Tulchin

column17: Henschel of Hainburg, Israel of Krems

column10: Rabbi Eliezer Yehuda Waldenberg (1915-2006) was a rabbi and dayan on the Supreme Rabbinical Court of Jerusalem and the foremost authority on medicine and halacha. He was known as the Tzitz Eliezer, after his monumental halachic treatise by that name, covering everything from Jewish ritual to medical ethics. It is widely considered to be one of the greatest halachic works of the 20th century.

Rabbi Menachem Nochum Twersky of Chernobyl (1730-1787), also known as the "Meor Einayim," was a student of the Baal Shem Tov and the Maggid of Mezritch. He was a gifted and enthusiastic orator for the early Hasidic movement. He became the maggid of Chernobyl and the founder of the Chernobyl dynasty, which includes many famous scions of the Twersky family.  He was the author of Meor Einayim, Chasidic insights into the weekly Torah portion and the holidays.
column19: Baal Shem Tov, Maggid of Mezritch

column17: Shmuel Tzvi Dancyger, Yerachmiel Yisroel Yitzchak Danziger
column25: For a complete picture of his family c.f Wikipedia

column10: Rabbi David Zvi Hoffmann (1843-1921) was the leading authority on halakha in Germany during his lifetime and a leading expert on midrash halakha. He had a doctorate from the University of Tubingen and taught Talmud, Halakha and Tanach in the rabbinical school of Rabbi Azriel Hildescheimer in Berlin, later becoming head of the Seminary. He was known for his scholarly refutations of the Documentary Hypothesis.

column25: Related to Moses Isserles and Shlomo Luria

column1: Aharon ben Jacob Ha-Kohen of Lunil
column3: אהרון בן יעקוב הכהן מן לונין

column1: Isaac ben Meir Halevi from Düren
column3: יצחק בן רבי מאיר הלוי מדורא

column10: Rabbi Aaron Samuel ben Israel Kaidanover (1614-1676) was a Polish-Lithuanian rabbi. Among his works were responsa, annotations on the Talmudic tractates of  Kedoshim, a commentary on Piskei HaRosh, and a partly kabbalistic commentary on the Chumash. He was the rabbi of Cracow at the time of his death.

Aharon ben Joseph HaLevi (d. 1290), known as the Ra'ah (רא"ה), was a Talmudic scholar, halakhist and rabbi. He was born in Gerona, Spain to a long line of rabbis reaching back to the Baal HaMaor.  He studied with his father, Rabbi Joseph HaLevi, as well as with Nachmanides. His best-known work is Bedek Habayit, critical notes on the Rashba's Torat HaBayit. He also wrote Talmudic commentaries. He had been claimed as the author of Sefer HaChinuch, but this identification is considered erroneous.
